bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 27, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg responds to Kean's suggestions regarding the ultimate disposition of the painting “Conquerors of Yellow Fever.” [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 27, 1941
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
November 27, 1941
Dear General Kean,
div1.p:
Your letter of November 22 has been read with
much interest. To date we have made no decision as to where
to permanently place the painting, “Conquerors of Yellow
Fever”.

I have talked over your proposal with Mr.
Withington of John Wyeth and Brother and we think both your
suggestions are excellent.

Of course, we will not be ready to place the
painting anywhere for permanent exhibition until such time as
it is no longer requested for temporary exhibition in various
parts of the country. All three paintings in the series are
at present travelling around the country for exhibitions in
medical schools, hospitals, and at medical society meetings.
We transport them and take care of them without charge for
the legitimate medical organizations who wish to exhibit them
and we expect to do this as long as there is a demand.

Another feature which influences our decision
is that some day it is possible that we may wish all eight or
ten paintings in the series in one place. If we knew how
soon the entire series would be completed and the new Army
Medical Library were interested they might arrange to provide
space for the entire series as a permanent loan. I would
question the advisability of John Wyeth and Brother ever giv-
ing them to any institution for the reason that even fifty
years from now it is quite possible that Wyeth will still wish
to reproduce these paintings and give them to another generation
of young physicians. Consequently, it would be rather absurd
for Wyeth to ask permission from some institution to reproduce
paintings originally sponsored by themselves. A change in per-
sonnel in any such institution might bring about a situation in
which that provision would be denied. However, if we were to
make a permanent loan, th[unclear]en Wyeth would still own the paintings
with the privilege of reproduction of them.

I think that this whole project is of consider-
able importance and at this time while the plans for the new
Medical Library are being formulated it will be an excellent
idea for me to come to Washington and talk the matter over with
-2-
you as well as the Surgeon General of the Army. I think that
General Ireland would probably be the person to get me into
contact with the present Surgeon General.

This whole project is one of those long term affairs
deserving of considerable planning in advance and I shall make
it a point to come down and see you as soon as I can get away
from this office for a couple of days.
Your interest is very much appreciated.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A Kellogg George A. Kellogg.
Gen. Jefferson R. Kean
2804 N Street, N W.,
Washington, D C.
